body.div:
February 7, 1916 My dear Mrs. Aldis:
What a brick you are! And how kind you have been to take such a lot of trouble on my behalf. I have telegraphed to Mr. Browne that the 19th of March would be the best date for me. It is awfully kind of you to want me to wait until April, and go to you at Lake Forest, but I am afraid I must get out there as quickly as possible, and I do not really know why I should not go out again later, if you think well enough of “The Grocery” to produce it at your theatre.
I do hope you are coming to Boston the end of this week. Why don’t you come to the Hotel Lowell? It is quite centrally situated, with automobile accommodation back and forth from the city. Of course, I know you have a sister-in-law living very near here, but sisters-in-law are like the poor, they are always with us; they will keep for an indefinite period. I believe your son is in Cambridge, and I must admit that we are not right beside Cambridge; but with the automobile accommodation I mentioned, it only takes fifteen minutes longer to get there. I do hope I shall hear from you, to say that you are coming, and coming here. Sincerely yours,
